messages.message:
Hi all, @Venkatesh is building an Advanced app and getting this licence error. He’s a part of the IB commercial org so shouldn’t get into issues with licences to do with AI Hub. 

This error shows FLOW as the app with the issue. What do I need to do to Venkatesh’s account licence to unblock this?
Which licence was adjusted here? We need to make sure these apps works with customers against their commercial context, not consuming credits from their community account.

Hey @Abhishek Adupa @Anil. We will soon have an air gapped environment and therefore have to train our clients on how to manage these things. Do we have any recordings or documentation for this?

cc: @Jason @Piyush

>  Which licence was adjusted here?
I adjusted the license mentioned in the error.
> Do we have any recordings or documentation for this?
If you are the admin of the environment, you should be able to access the license page (https://aihub.preprod.instabase.com/apps/admin/licenses/detail/018e2e5675a47475916d32afe209beb2), there’s an adjust credits option.
@hannah when creating advanced apps we are using community licences not commercial by default. Is this something that’s known?

> We need to make sure these apps works with customers against their commercial context, not consuming credits from their community account.
I’m not sure how the AI Hub licenses operate within commercial and community contexts. CCing @mfichman to help clarify this.

Wait - only our soleng team should be creating advanced apps (using existing platform capabilities on AI Hub environments). There is a license that is needed to build these apps (which can just be something behind the scenes such as a community account as this license is intended to give access to existing platform capabilities).

Once this is packaged into an app and brought into AI Hub, it uses the org license to run it. I want to make sure we don't mix up the license for development of the app from the license needed to run the app.

Got you. So when one of our team is building we need to make sure they have enough community units to be able to test during development. 

During run no changes are needed as it will consume units in the context it is being run.

There was confusion because @Venkatesh is in our community org, and developing using the platform UI, but that’s defaulting to using community. Which is fine if that’s the plan and doesn’t affect users during run.

I think we still need to figure out a different licensing strategy to ensure that users don't error out like this when building advanced apps, but the general premise is that only our internal teams for new customers should be building in the same AI Hub environment (with exception of federal). All new customers should never see anything outside of their org.

cc: @andy @Adam @Travis as this is directly related to our convos on advanced apps :slightly_smiling_face:
Also, @Venkatesh is working on federal, so we might have hit the exceptional case.
